title: SWAPNOCHAR
detailsOfAchievement: SWAPNOCHAR entered into the arena with its first-ever production Harano Prabhat (The Lost Dawn) on 9th July, 2000. The group ventured its glorious journey with a bunch of spirited youths with Md. Selim at its helm. Surpassing torrents of turmoil and thorn â€“ridden path, the dream chariot of SWAPNACHAR has reached its youth leaving past an exciting adolescence. From its initiation till today SWAPNOCHARs kitty is full with some notable productions like Kalo Ghora (Black Stallion) in 2001. Poetry and physical acting merged in the making of its 2002 production â€“ Unmad Bikshipto Somayer Tarjama (Interpretation of the Insane, Tumultuous Time). With this production SWAPNOCHAR succeeded in attracting the curiosity of the cultured community. In the meantime, besides theatrical activities, SWAPNOCHAR published Ghoon, a literary magazine. It has also touched the heart of serious readers of Bengal. Our next production Mukhosh (Mask) (2003) received overwhelming applause both as a street play and a proscenium play. SWAPNACHAR was invited to present this production in the Kolkata Natyamela (Theatre Festival)â€“2003 organized by the W B Government. In 2004 we produced 21er Diary (Diary of the 21st Century) that depicts the new-wave psyche and life-style of Gen-Y. The play revolves round the decaying and corrupt ethos of the present day socio-economic life that gives birth to crippled thoughts. We were again invited to the W B Government Theatre Festival to stage this play in 2004. Spectators still fondly remember the ripples it created on the psyche of the conscious and caring theatre-goers.

detailsOfAchievement: i.We have undertaken several health awareness programmes such as mother and child health programme, adolescence problems awareness programme in schools and colleges, Cancer detection camps, Dermatological camps, AIDS and TB awareness camps, Diabetic detection camps etc. during the last 10 years in rural and slums of urban areas ii.We have completed Trainers Training Camp for medical and paramedical personnel on Arsenicosis in different arsenic affected blocks of West Bengal sponsored by Ministry of Environment and Forest, Govt. of India. iii.We have also performed National Environmental Awareness Campaigning programmes in rural and urban areas sponsored by Ministry of Environment and Forest, Govt. of India. iv. We have completed Baseline survey and Socio-economic survey of the households in about 250 arsenic affected villages under 7 districts of West Bengal and 25 villages under Sahibganj district under Jharkhand state through the Project of Community based Project to Mitigate Arsenic Pollution in West Bengal sponsored by Indo-Canada Environment Facility (ICEF),New Delhi and All India Institute of Hygiene and Public Health,Kolkata. v.We have also undertaken Socio-economical survey works and Local Economic Development works and Self Help Group training programmes in Serampore and Baidyabati municipal area under KUSP project. vi.We are periodically doing Chemical and Bacteriological analysis of water sample collected from Serampore, Champdani Municipaliy. For this purpose we have many Resource persons and infrastructure in our organisation for performing this type of jobs. vii.We are regularly publishing a health care report in the form of monthly newspaper SWASTHYA BHABNA MASIK.

detailsOfAchievement: swatirtha charitable trust is a registered trust having its own registered office at rabindra palli suri birbhum wb 731101 has started its operation during the year 2011 the mission of the trust is to train the youth power with technical and vocational skills and empowering the target group with knowledge and skill accross various sectors thus enabling them to earn socio economic status the strategic objective of the trust includes establishing various educational technical vocational institutions skill development centers with desired out come for the benifit of the target group without any profit motive income tax department has been pleased to issue 80g and 12a certificate to the trust keeping into view its charitable activities institutes and training centers running under the umbrella of swatirtha charitable trust ns polytechnic college approved by aicte and affiliated to wbsct and ve and sd since year 2012 is running with four trades in two shifts with separate hostels for boys and girls ns private iti with approval of dget and with accreditation of qci is running with four trades since year 2015 with intake of 210 students ns b ed college with recognition of ercncte bhubaneswar and with affiliation of the university of burdwan with 100 intake capacit since year 2015 ns d el ed college with recognition of ercncte and with affiliation of wbbpe with annual intake capacity 50 running since year 2016 vocational training centers since year 2012 carried out activities for imparting skill related to employability and enterprenurship training offering short term skill training courses in different towns and villages Further swatirtha charitable trust has become a private training provider to run four govt iti at binpur nayagram sagar and patharpratima for this an agreement has been made between govt of wb consortium and nsdc Thus today Swatirtha Charitable Trust has developed sturdy organizational competencies in the field of Technical and Vocational Education and Skill Training with a highly motivated and dedicated team of skilled personnel and ready to accept any challenge in the domain to realize its mission

title: THEATRE IN EDUCATION
detailsOfAchievement: TIE refers to a coordinated set of theatre-based educational activities that are generally centered on a subject that has relevance to both the childrenâ€™s lives as well as the school curriculum. An array of studies have demonstrated the benefits of TIE in positively improving young peopleâ€™s knowledge, attitudes and behavior in relation to various life skills and health topics, including: health risk behaviors such as AIDS/HIV and smoking; nutrition and healthy eating; financial literacy; social issues, and; bullying. A review of the literature of TIE reveals a wide variety of program characteristics, including: the use of puppets or actors; inclusion of follow-up classroom activities; the use of music; participatory techniques such as role playing, and; research/theory based performances. The effectiveness of TIE programs will be discussed according to these criteria, to determine how the different program characteristics may contribute to the success or otherwise of such programs.
